sect1.title: How to begin
sect1.para: The following daps tutorial helps beginners to write and convert XML-files, for example into PDF- or HTML-files. It is no previous xml-knowledge necessary.

First of all you need a XML compatible editor, for example emacs. Your filename should always end with ".xml" to have a better overview. Advisable especially for beginners is the daps-init file which creates a template for daps with different examples. If you want to work without daps-init, you have to paste this header (see ):

example.title: Header of a DocBook file
example.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <!DOCTYPE article PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.5//EN" "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.5/docbookx.dtd" [
<!ENTITY tdg "DocBook: The Definitive Guide">
]>

callout.para: The general syntax for a document type declaration

sect1.para: Don't be afraid if you don't understand the header. Just copy and paste it in your file.

First and foremost the most important thing you have to know about XML is that you always need a starttag and a endtag. The content depends on which element you want to create. The first decision you have to make is whether you want to write a book or an article. These two types of text can be created with xml. If you want to write an article you have to paste an article start- and endtag. Between these two tags you can write your text.
Otherwise you have to write "book" instead of article. In the following tutorial i only describe how to write an article because the book-option is almost equal.
